I believe that my initial forecast of 15% was a large overestimate and if I were to look at the same data today, I believe that my forecast would be around 2%. My reason for the large change in perspective is that I recently thought about how China and nations in general tend to avoid direct conflict. More specifically, the CCP has been claiming the island of Taiwan as theirs for decades, though they have not taken any real military action. In the past few years, China has risen to become a country that could rival the United States in terms of military strength, and very well could take over Taiwan but they continue to hold back. I believe this to also be true for the conflicting borders with India; they want the land but really do not want to start a military conflict with a strong militarized nation. If China were to start a conflict within the next few months, I believe that it would be over Taiwan or the South China Sea, not the Himalayas. As a result, I believe that there would be a 0.5% chance of China wanting to participate in a real conflict with India, and a 1.5% chance of a lethal confrontation (1 death) occurring as an accident. Though, it was brought to my attention in last Thursday's lecture that India has sent 50,000 troops to this disputed border (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-27/india-shifts-50-000-troops-to-china-border-in-historic-defense-shift). Though this is an act of aggression from India, I do not believe that China will want to retaliate in a way that would cause conflict. As I mentioned earlier, China is more focused on claiming Taiwan and the South China Sea. Even with this in mind, this move from India should not be ignored with regard to this forecast as more troops creates more potential for accidents to happen. I raise my forecast on the chance of an accidental lethal confrontation from 1.5% to 2.5%, giving me a 3% total probability.
Given currently no additional news regarding rise in tension, and the shorter horizon left, I would say that my prediction is 0.5%.

I am adjusting my estimate after some of the Superforecasting lectures. Let us first look at this historical base rate. The only reasonable place where this lethal confrontation could occur is on the China-India border, as it seems extremely unlikely that there would be an all out war that would draw in India and China somewhere else that arises within the next 5 months. Now let's look at the documented data from a reputable source: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/17/world/asia/india-china-border-clashes.html. There was a clearly lethal war between India and China in 1962, a lethal conflict in 1967, and the lethal conflict in 2020. This is out of a history of the border since 1914, about 100 years. So the historical base rate seems to be about 3/100 = 3% per year, which yields a rate of 1.5% per half year (about 5 months). This isn't really fair to say however considering the India China border is over the Himalaya Mountains which are more usable in the summer months, and the bulk of summer/early fall in 2021 is yet to come and is before Dec 1 2021, so let's say that the historical base rate for this conflict occurring between July 1 (essentially) and Dec 1 of a given year is about 2/3 of the chance of the conflict of the entire year, so 2%. However, we also need to take the inside view after considering this base rate. As noted in my previous forecast, due to COVID 19 and various international relations, it seems that this event occurring in the next 5 months is less likely than the historical mean. China and India, in particular India, have more pressing concerns than border conflicts at the moment. So I place this probability at 1%.

China and India both are facing crises currently -- India with a well-documented COVID-19 crisis (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/10/india-covid-crisis-more-than-6000-deaths-recorded-in-24-hours.html) and China with a diminishing international reputation due to the prevalence of the Wuhan lab leak theory (https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/07/politics/covid-lab-leak-theory-classified-report/index.html0. China in particular cannot afford more decline to its international reputation, with the aforementioned theory gaining popularity, and the general declining state of US-China relations in recent years over economic and political dominance, especially in 2020 with the COVID crisis and the Trump administration's response (https://www.cfr.org/article/how-2020-shaped-us-china-relations). Based on some of the causes of recent rise of violence against those of Asian descent in America, it is fair to say that this declining relationship exacerbated by COVID has yielded violent anti-China sentiment in a non-negligible subset of the American people -- this seems like a reasonable conclusion based on articles such as https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/05/26/the-politics-of-anti-asian-racism/. So among some Americans at least, there is the undercurrent of support of anti-China behavior, in particular military behavior. With the aggressive foreign policy stance of the Biden administration (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-55945942) and its declining relationship and perception by Americans, China should and will avoid aggressive conflict with America, likely reflecting in the behavior of their troops along their border.
